name: hard coal, import from Australia | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18234/documentation

This activity represents import of hard coal from Australia. India imports coal from many countries in the world to meet its growing energy demands. As per the provisional coal statistics 2015-16, Ministry of coal. India imported 199.884 million tones of coal in the year 2015-16. The countries from where coal was mainly imported were Indonesia , Australia  and south Africa. Out of the overall import , Indonesia contributed to around 48.12 % , Australia contributed to around 23.79 % and South Africa contributed around 18.05 %. 

The activity starts with 1 ton coal at Australian ports ready to be exported to India

This module includes the transport of the coal from Australia  to ports in India
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature Data: The import data for coal has been taken from Provisional coal Statistics 2016-17. While for the average distance online maps have been used to calculate average distance between Australia and various Indian Ports. Provisional Coal Statistics 2016-17 can be downloaded from http://www.coalcontroller.gov.in/pages/view/44-provisional-coal-statistics

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description: Transportation Losses: Transit and Handling losses taken into account. The values have been taken as per CERC (Central Electricity regulatory Commision) guidelines which gives a loss of 0.2 % as transit and handling loss for pit head thermal power plants  and 0.8 % as transit and handling loss for other power plants. The value taken here is 0.8%.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Own Assumption based on Literature data. Transit and Handling losses taken into account. The values have been taken as per CERC (Central Electricity regulatory Commision) guidelines which gives a loss of 0.2 % as transit and handling loss for pit head thermal power plants  and 0.8 % as transit and handling loss for other power plants, The value taken here is 0.8%
